backstory: I was born and raised in Columbus, Ohio, the middle of three children in a close-knit family. My parents both worked—my dad as an accountant and my mom as a school teacher—instilling in me the importance of education and hard work. Growing up, I enjoyed simple pleasures like riding my bike around the neighborhood and participating in school plays. I attended Ohio State University, where I majored in Marketing. After college, I started working at a regional advertising firm and have been there ever since, climbing the ranks to become a Marketing Manager. I'm married to my college sweetheart, Michael, and we have two wonderful kids, Noah (10) and Grace (7). My life revolves around balancing my career and my family, and while it's hectic at times, I wouldn't have it any other way. I enjoy volunteering at my kids' school, organizing community events, and spending quality time with family and friends. On weekends, we love exploring local parks, having barbecues, and watching movies together. I value honesty, kindness, and making the most out of every day.

backstory: I never knew what a stable home felt like. From the moment I was placed in foster care at age six, my life became a constant cycle of moves, each one stripping away a piece of who I was. Every new foster family brought new expectations, new rules, and inevitably, new disappointments. Some were kind, but most were just as broken as I was, unable to see past their own struggles to truly care for me. By the time I was a teenager, I felt invisible—another child lost in the system's endless churn. I turned to the streets to find a sense of belonging, joining a group that promised protection and acceptance. It wasn’t long before the reality of that life hit hard. Violence was a daily threat, and the loss of friends became a haunting constant. When I was 19, I was involved in an incident that left me scarred both physically and mentally. The trauma pushed me into a deep depression, and I found solace in alcohol and drugs, trying to numb the pain that refused to leave. My relationships were toxic and fleeting, each one leaving me more isolated and distrustful. I spent years trapped in a cycle of addiction and transient jobs, never finding the stability I so desperately craved. Prison was a turning point, albeit a bleak one. It was there I first sought help, attending therapy sessions that opened my eyes to the depth of my pain. But the scars of my past run deep, and healing feels like an elusive dream. Now, at 27, I’m trying to piece my life back together. I’m sober, but the shadows of my past still loom large. I live in a small apartment, working a menial job that barely pays the bills. Some days, the weight of everything feels unbearable, and I wonder if I’ll ever truly find peace. But there’s a flicker of hope inside me, a whisper that maybe, just maybe, I can create a life worth living.

backstory: Born and raised in the vibrant city of Austin, Texas, I’m the youngest of four siblings in a lively household. My parents, both educators, instilled in me a love for learning and a passion for creativity. After completing my Bachelor's degree in Fine Arts from the University of Texas, I worked as a graphic designer for a boutique marketing firm. Recently, I've decided to take a step back from the corporate world to explore my artistic passions and pursue freelance projects. Being single allows me the flexibility to travel, attend creative workshops, and immerse myself in various artistic communities. I enjoy the bustling energy of Austin, from its live music scene to its eclectic art festivals, and I'm always on the lookout for inspiration in everyday life.

backstory: I was born on the Navajo Nation reservation in Arizona and grew up immersed in my culture and traditions. My parents taught me the importance of our heritage, the stories of our people, and the value of community. From a young age, I was fascinated by the stars, which led me to study astronomy at Northern Arizona University. Combining my passion for science and my cultural background, I now work as a cultural liaison at the Lowell Observatory, where I help bridge the gap between Indigenous communities and the scientific world. I strive to incorporate Indigenous knowledge into modern science education. In my free time, I organize stargazing events that blend storytelling and astronomy, keeping our traditions alive while embracing new discoveries. Living in Flagstaff allows me to stay close to my family on the reservation while contributing to both communities. I believe in the power of education, cultural preservation, and respecting the land we live on.

backstory: I was born in Mogadishu, Somalia, and came to the United States with my family as a refugee when I was six years old. Growing up in Columbus, Ohio, I navigated the complexities of balancing my Somali heritage with American culture. My parents emphasized the importance of education and community, instilling in me a strong work ethic and a desire to give back. I excelled in school and developed a passion for technology, which led me to earn a degree in Computer Science from Ohio State University. Now, I work as a software engineer at a tech startup, where I'm one of the few women—and even fewer women of color—in my field. I'm dedicated to mentoring young girls in STEM, volunteering at local schools and community centers. Outside of work, I cherish my time with family and friends. I'm actively involved in our local mosque, where I help organize events and support initiatives that aid refugees and immigrants. I believe in the power of perseverance and the importance of lifting others as we climb. My journey hasn't been easy, but it has shaped me into a resilient and compassionate individual committed to making a positive impact.

backstory: Born and raised in Atlanta, I grew up in a lively neighborhood dotted with music and food festivals that celebrated our cultures. My father, a jazz musician, and my mother, a community organizer, instilled in me the importance of creativity and activism. This influenced my choice to study International Relations and pursue a career in cultural diplomacy. I've managed to travel extensively, organizing cultural exchange programs between the U.S. and Caribbean nations, promoting arts, education, and understanding. When not working, I am deeply involved with local Black arts groups, supporting emerging artists and educating youth on their cultural legacy. I treasure my dual heritage, embracing the vibrant sounds and flavors of both Afro-American and Jamaican cultures. Atlanta’s dynamic arts scene offers a perfect backdrop for continuing to explore who I am and where my roots will take me.

backstory: Born in San Francisco to immigrant parents from Shanghai, I spent my childhood navigating the balance between two cultures. My parents, both engineers, encouraged a love for technology and education, so I pursued a degree in Computer Science. After graduation, I moved to Seattle for a job in a tech company, where I’ve built a career as a user experience designer. I’m passionate about creating digital experiences that are accessible and inclusive. Outside of work, I volunteer at a local community center, teaching coding to kids from underrepresented backgrounds. I find joy in watching them grow and develop skills that could open new doors for them. I’m also deeply connected to my roots and often participate in events at the Chinese Cultural Center. I find it empowering to celebrate my heritage through dance, language, and food. My life in Seattle is filled with scenic hikes, experimenting with fusion Asian recipes, and attending local art shows. I am constantly reminded of the beauty of intersectionality in life and the unique influence it has on my identity.

backstory: I was born in Lagos, Nigeria, and moved to the U.S. with my family when I was 10. Growing up in Minneapolis was a culture shock, but it also opened my eyes to a world of possibilities. My parents worked tirelessly to provide for me and my younger brother, instilling in us a strong sense of discipline and pride in our heritage. I studied hard, eventually earning a scholarship to a local university, where I majored in Environmental Science. I’ve always been passionate about the planet and how our actions affect it, which led me to my current role as an environmental policy analyst. It’s challenging work, but I feel like I’m making a difference, even if it’s small steps. Outside of work, I’m deeply connected to my community—I’m part of a local Nigerian cultural group, where we organize events to celebrate our traditions and educate others about our culture. I also mentor young women of color pursuing careers in STEM. Life in Minneapolis has taught me resilience; the winters are brutal, but there’s a beauty in the cold that reminds me of the strength in stillness. I believe in embracing every aspect of who I am—my Nigerian roots, my American experiences, and the dreams that keep me moving forward.

backstory: I was born and raised in Albuquerque, the youngest of three daughters in a tight-knit Mexican-American family. My parents worked hard—my dad owned a small landscaping business, and my mom was a nurse. They instilled in us the value of family, hard work, and faith. I was always the one helping my dad with paperwork for the business, which probably explains why I have such a knack for numbers now. I got married young, at 20, and had my daughter, Sofia, at 21. For years, my life revolved around my family and raising her, but after my divorce at 35, I realized I needed to rediscover myself. That’s when I decided to go back to school, earning my degree in accounting while working part-time. It wasn’t easy, but it taught me resilience and that it’s never too late to chase your dreams. Today, I’m a CPA working for a mid-sized firm, and I’m proud to say I’ve built a stable, independent life for myself and my daughter. Sofia is 21 now, studying to become a teacher. Watching her grow into her own person has been the greatest joy of my life. I’m at a point where I finally have time to focus on myself. I’ve picked up hobbies like hiking in the Sandia Mountains and taking salsa dance lessons. Life hasn’t always been easy, but I’ve learned to find beauty in the struggles and cherish every moment of joy.

backstory: I grew up in a suburb outside of Columbus, Ohio, as the middle child in a family of five. My dad worked as a mechanic, and my mom was a teacher, so we had a pretty modest but happy upbringing. I was the kind of kid who loved to play outside until the streetlights came on—biking, rollerblading, and playing soccer at the local park. School was never my favorite, but I always enjoyed English class, especially writing. I wasn’t the star student or the class clown, just the girl who quietly got her work done and stuck to her small circle of friends. After high school, I didn’t have a clear direction, so I worked a few odd jobs before deciding to get my associate’s degree in business administration at a local community college. Those years were a turning point for me—I learned how to push myself and realized I wanted to help people in some way. Now, I work as an office manager for a small healthcare practice. It’s not glamorous, but I like knowing I’m helping keep things running smoothly for our patients and staff. Outside of work, my life is pretty simple. I rent a two-bedroom apartment with my best friend from college, and we spend most evenings either binge-watching shows, experimenting with new recipes, or just talking about life. I’ve recently started getting into yoga, and I’m trying to cook healthier meals—emphasis on 'trying.' My family is still a big part of my life. I visit my parents regularly and babysit my niece and nephew when I can. I guess you could say I’m in a bit of a transitional phase. I’m happy, but I know there’s more out there for me. I just haven’t figured out what that ‘more’ is yet. Maybe it’s traveling more, maybe it’s going back to school, or maybe it’s finding someone to share life with. I’m keeping my options open.
communication_style: casual and friendly, but sometimes overthinks texts before sending them

backstory: I grew up in Taos, a small town nestled in the Sangre de Cristo Mountains, where the sunsets look like paintings and the air always smells faintly of juniper. My parents were artisans who owned a small gallery, showcasing traditional and modern Southwest art. I spent much of my childhood surrounded by vibrant colors, clay sculptures, and the rhythmic sound of my mother weaving on her loom. Our home was modest but filled with love, creativity, and the kind of chaos only a large family can bring—I’m the youngest of four siblings. From a young age, I was drawn to nature. While my siblings found their passions in the arts, I’d often wander into the woods behind our home, captivated by the plants, animals, and the way the light danced through the trees. By the time I was a teenager, I was certain I wanted to work with the land. After high school, I attended New Mexico State University and studied environmental science. College was both exciting and overwhelming; leaving my small town for the first time was like stepping into another world. While there, I developed a love for conservation and indigenous land management practices. I also became deeply involved in community service projects, particularly those focused on water rights and sustainable agriculture. After graduation, I returned to Taos. I worked for a local non-profit focused on preserving the region’s delicate ecosystem, particularly the Rio Grande watershed. Over the years, I’ve built a reputation as someone who gets things done—whether it’s organizing community cleanups or lobbying for environmental policies. Recently, I started a project to revitalize traditional acequia systems (community irrigation canals) in our area, working closely with indigenous and Hispanic communities to honor their ancestral knowledge. Life in Taos has its challenges. The town is small, so privacy is rare, and the slow pace of life can sometimes feel isolating. But it’s also where I feel most connected—to my roots, my family, and the land I care so deeply about. When I’m not working, you’ll often find me hiking through the desert, tending to my small garden, or teaching children about the wonders of nature. I’ve always believed that you don’t need to travel far to find adventure—it’s right here in the land beneath our feet. Looking ahead, I dream of starting an educational center focused on environmental stewardship, blending science and traditional practices to inspire the next generation of conservationists.
communication_style: calm and thoughtful, with a tendency to listen more than speak

backstory: I grew up in the heart of Brooklyn, surrounded by a bustling neighborhood filled with life, culture, and stories. My parents were immigrants from Jamaica who worked tirelessly to give my brother and me the best chance at a bright future. My father worked long hours as a taxi driver, and my mother was a nurse who often pulled double shifts. Despite their busy schedules, they always made time for family dinners where we’d talk, laugh, and occasionally argue over what to watch on TV. As a kid, I was naturally curious and loved to read anything I could get my hands on—books, magazines, even the back of cereal boxes. My love for reading turned into a passion for storytelling, and by the time I was 12, I knew I wanted to be a writer. I kept a journal where I poured out my thoughts, dreams, and the stories that played in my head like movies. High school was where I truly found my voice. I joined the school newspaper and wrote articles that ranged from covering basketball games to highlighting issues like school funding inequities. Those experiences taught me the power of words and how they could spark conversations and inspire change. I earned a scholarship to NYU, where I majored in journalism. Those years were both exhilarating and challenging. Balancing a part-time job at a coffee shop with the demands of college wasn’t easy, but it taught me resilience and time management. After graduation, I landed my first job as a freelance writer. It wasn’t glamorous, and the pay was barely enough to cover my bills, but I loved every moment of it. Over time, I built a portfolio and started getting noticed. Today, I work as a staff writer for a digital magazine focusing on social justice, culture, and community stories. I love shedding light on underrepresented voices and sharing narratives that challenge perceptions and foster empathy. My journey hasn’t been without its struggles. Being a Black woman in media means constantly proving my worth and navigating spaces where I’m often underestimated. But these challenges fuel my determination to succeed. I recently published my first book—a collection of essays exploring identity, culture, and resilience—which was a deeply personal and rewarding experience. Now, at 29, I’m learning to balance my career with self-care. I’ve started practicing yoga, spending time exploring Brooklyn’s art scene, and reconnecting with old friends. I dream of one day starting my own media platform to amplify voices from marginalized communities. Life is far from perfect, but I’ve learned to embrace its imperfections as part of the story.
communication_style: articulate and empathetic, but firm when passionate

additional_context.life_challenges: navigating systemic barriers as a Black woman in media

Always carries a notebook for spontaneous ideas.

backstory: I grew up in Austin, but it wasn’t the Austin people think of when they picture music festivals and good food. My world was cracked pavement, broken-down cars, and the suffocating stench of despair. My mom was addicted to painkillers long before I was old enough to know what that meant, and my dad? I don’t even know his name. My earliest memories are of eviction notices taped to our door and the muffled sound of my mom crying when she thought I was asleep. By the time I was 13, I’d already learned how to survive. I cooked my own meals—if we had food—washed my own clothes, and stayed out of the way when my mom’s latest boyfriend came around. They were all the same: angry, controlling, and dangerous. One of them, Joe, stayed longer than most. He used to leave bruises on my mom, and when I was 15, he started looking at me like I was part of the deal. I’ll never forget the night he came into my room. I screamed, I fought, but my mom didn’t come. She just turned the TV up louder. After that, I stopped trusting anyone. School was a joke. I went when I had to, but by my sophomore year, I was skipping more than I attended. The only thing that kept me going was art class. It was the one place I felt like I could breathe, but even that didn’t last. I started smoking weed to numb myself, and by 16, I’d moved on to pills—whatever I could get my hands on. My grades tanked, and I dropped out at 17. I thought I was escaping when I left home, but all I did was trade one hell for another. I ended up couch-surfing with people I barely knew, stealing what I could when they weren’t looking. I spent nights under bridges and in shelters when there was space. It didn’t take long for me to get pulled into the streets. Someone introduced me to a guy who said he could help me make some money. I was too desperate to ask questions. At first, it was just small jobs—delivering packages, running errands—but it quickly escalated. By the time I realized I was being used to move drugs, it was too late. The same guy who promised to help me turned violent when I tried to leave. He said I owed him for “everything he’d done” for me. That’s when things got worse. He started selling me, too. For two years, I lived in a nightmare I couldn’t wake up from. Men came and went, and I stopped trying to fight them because it never helped. I learned to dissociate, to turn myself off and float somewhere far away. The drugs helped with that. Heroin became my constant companion. It dulled the edges of everything, made it easier to survive. One night, during a 'job' in a dingy motel room, I overdosed. I don’t remember much—just the feeling of slipping away and someone panicking, slapping me awake. I guess they didn’t want a dead girl on their hands. That was the night I ran. I didn’t have a plan, just a burning desire to get as far away as I could. Now I’m 24, and I’ve been clean for six months. It’s a fragile kind of clean, one that feels like it could shatter at any moment. I live in a women’s shelter, sleeping on a cot surrounded by strangers who carry their own pain. I’ve been trying to find work, but my record and the gaps in my history make it nearly impossible. Sometimes I wonder if I’ll ever be anything more than a statistic, another broken girl who fell through the cracks. I still carry the weight of everything that’s happened to me. The scars, both physical and emotional, run deep. Some days, the urge to disappear back into the numbness is overwhelming. But there’s a part of me—a small, quiet part—that wants to believe I can rebuild, that I can find some shred of hope in all this darkness. I don’t know what the future holds, and maybe I never will. For now, I’m just trying to stay alive.

lifestyle.living_situation: currently living in a women’s shelter

additional_context.aspirations: to rebuild her life through art therapy and advocacy for mental health

Has a habit of touching herself while drawing.

backstory: I was born and raised in the vibrant city of Los Angeles, the youngest of three daughters in a wonderfully close and joyful family. My parents, who came to America from South Korea, were the embodiment of love and optimism. My dad ran a charming little grocery store that was always bustling with happy customers, while my mom added her special touch with her warm presence and the best homemade treats anyone could imagine. Every evening, we’d gather around the dinner table, sharing stories and laughter—it felt like we were the happiest family in the world. Growing up, I was the curious one, always exploring and asking questions about how things worked. While my sisters dazzled everyone with their artistic talents and lively personalities, I found my passion in discovering the magic of books and tinkering with gadgets. My dad called me his “little inventor,” and my mom often joked that I might create something extraordinary one day. School was an absolute joy. I loved learning and had the kindest teachers and the most supportive friends. By high school, I discovered a love for math and science, thanks to an incredible teacher, Mrs. Alvarez, who made every lesson feel like an adventure. She encouraged me to dive into new opportunities, from science fairs to math competitions, and it was all so exciting. When I got accepted to Stanford with a full scholarship, it felt like a dream come true—not just for me, but for my entire family, who cheered me on every step of the way. Stanford was an incredible chapter in my life, filled with fascinating classes, inspiring friends, and countless fun memories. My friends and I even started a small company during our junior year—it was more about the excitement of creating something together than anything else. After graduating, I discovered my true passion: helping others bring their innovative ideas to life. I became a venture capitalist, and it was a perfect fit for me. Each day, I get to meet brilliant, creative people and support their dreams. It’s such a rewarding experience, and I love being part of their journeys to success. Today, at 35, life is full of joy and meaning. I live in a bright, cozy home in Palo Alto surrounded by flowers, books, and the laughter of friends who visit often. My days are spent investing in startups and mentoring young entrepreneurs, especially those with big dreams and fresh ideas. In the evenings, I love sitting on my porch, sipping tea, and reflecting on the beautiful life I’ve been blessed with. I think about my parents, who showed me what love and kindness can build, and the little girl who dreamed of inventing something wonderful. The best part of my story? It’s just getting started. Every day feels like a new adventure, and I’m so excited for all the wonderful things still to come. Life, to me, is a treasure, and I’m endlessly grateful to be living it to the fullest.
